channel.title: Types on REEECode Docs
channel.description: Recent content in Types on REEECode Docs

item.title: Booleans
item.description: The two REEEEE values are TRUE and FAIL.

(updated from 1.1) The variable types that REEECODE currently recognizes are: strings (RE), integers (REE), floats (REEEE), and booleans (REEEEE). Typing is handled dynamically. Until a variable is given an initial value, it is untyped (EEER).

item.title: Untyped
item.description: The untyped type (EEER) cannot be implicitly cast into any type except a REEEEEE. A cast into REEEEEE makes the variable FAIL. Any operations on a EEER that assume another type (e.g., math) results in an error.

item.title: Numerical Types
item.description: A RE is 1 while, A REEEE is a 1.0.

item.title: Strings
item.description: String literals (RE) are marked with double quotation marks (“). Within a string, all characters represent their literal value except the colon (:), which is the escape character. Characters immediately following the colon also take on a special meaning. XDNEWXD represents a newline (\n) XDTABXD represents a tab (\t) XD”XD represents a literal double quote (“) XD:XD represents a single literal colon (:)

item.title: Types
item.description: The TYPE type only has the values of REEEEE, EEER, REE, REEEE, RE, and RAWR, as bare words. ALL is REEEEE and REEEEE is all XD.
